elements.content: Twelve Cu(I) coordination polymers, [CuCl(L1)] n (1), [Cu4I4(L1)2] n (2), {[Cu2I2(L1)]·0.5I2} n (3), [Cu3I3(L1)] n (4), [Cu2Br2(L1)] n (5), [CuBr(L1)] n (6), [Cu2Cl2(L1)] n (7), [Cu2Br2(L2)] n (8), [CuBr(L2)] n (9), [CuI(L2)] n (10), [Cu3I3(L2)] n (11), and Cu2I2(L3)2 (12) (L1 = 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, L2 = 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole and L3 = 4-amino-3,5-bis(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole), have been prepared and structurally characterized. In these compounds, 4-amino-3,5-bis(n-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (n-bpt) exhibits different coordination modes tuned by the isomeric effect and the anion effect, forming various architectures by bridging a variety of CuX (X = Cl, Br, or I) building units. Compound 1 presents a layer structure with (4, 4) topology built by bridging adjacent (CuCl)∞ chains with L1. Compound 2 shows an unusual one-dimensional strap structure by linking a rare Cu8I8 unit with L1. Compounds 3 and 4 present two-dimensional layers with (6, 3) topology. Compound 5 shows a three-dimensional ZnCl2 network with {3.6.74}{3.62.73}2 topology. Compound 6 exhibits a layer with (4, 82) network topology. A complicated three-dimensional framework for 7 is constructed with unique {6.82}2{6.85} topology. Compounds 8 and 9 are both chains, and hydrogen-bonding and π−π interactions play important roles in stabilizing the extended structure. Compound 10 is a layer with (4, 4) topology. An interesting double layer compound exhibiting complicated structure is found for 11. Compound 12 is a zero-periodic compound. The luminescent properties of compounds 4−6, 8, 9, and 12 have been investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: Twelve coordination compounds with diverse structures have been constructed by three isomers linking various inorganic copper(I) halide building blocks. The structural features of these compounds and the influencing factors are discussed. The isomeric effect and anion effect play an important role in structural construction.

elements.content: The design and construction of coordination polymers have attracted extensive interest in recent years, due to their various structural topologies and potential applications in gas absorption and separation, catalysis, and the development of electronic, optical, magnetic, and sensing materials. It is well-known that the properties of coordination polymers are heavily influenced by their structures. Therefore, it is important for crystal engineering to investigate the factors influencing the structural construction of functional compounds. Although large numbers of coordination polymers with interesting structures and excellent properties have been widely reported in recent years, it still remains a challenging task to explore effective synthetic strategies for the preparation of coordination polymers with expected structure and properties. The structures of coordination polymers are frequently affected by organic ligands, inorganic units, and correlative reaction conditions, such as the pH value of solution, the ratio of metal-to-ligand, the counteranion, and so on. Among these factors, the organic ligand plays a crucial role. Even the minor structural change of the ligand such as the angle, distance, and relative orientation of the donor or functional groups can result in the variation of the coordination framework. In this regard, utilizing isomeric ligands which have the same bridge part but different coordination characteristics as a system is considered to be an effective way to investigate the influence of organic ligand on the resultant structure.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of coordination polymers have attracted extensive interest in recent years, due to their various structural topologies and potential applications in gas absorption and separation, catalysis, and the development of electronic, optical, magnetic, and sensing materials. It is well-known that the properties of coordination polymers are heavily influenced by their structures. Therefore, it is important for crystal engineering to investigate the factors influencing the structural construction of functional compounds. Although large numbers of coordination polymers with interesting structures and excellent properties have been widely reported in recent years, it still remains a challenging task to explore effective synthetic strategies for the preparation of coordination polymers with expected structure and properties. The structures of coordination polymers are frequently affected by organic ligands, inorganic units, and correlative reaction conditions, such as the pH value of solution, the ratio of metal-to-ligand, the counteranion, and so on. Among these factors, the organic ligand plays a crucial role. Even the minor structural change of the ligand such as the angle, distance, and relative orientation of the donor or functional groups can result in the variation of the coordination framework. In this regard, utilizing isomeric ligands which have the same bridge part but different coordination characteristics as a system is considered to be an effective way to investigate the influence of organic ligand on the resultant structure.

elements.content: We are interested in building coordination polymers with isomeric ligands. Three isomers of 4-amino-3,5-bis(n-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, namely, 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, and 4-amino-3,5-bis(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole, were designed and synthesized based on the following reasons. First of all, the three isomers have different bent angles when they coordinate to metals because the pyridyl N-donor (Npyridyl) lies in different sites in the same bridge part. Meantime, L2 and L3 will form different conformations when pyridyl cycles spin along the C−C bond between pyridyl cycles and triazole cycles. Configuration isomerism and conformational isomerism will lead to different coordination modes of ligands. From compounds constructed by L1, L2, and L3 reacting with transition metal ions, we found that the coordination mode presented by the ligand isomers has a tuning effect on the resultant crystal structures. Furthermore, the backbone part of isomers (4-amino-1,2,4-triazole) can also provide nitrogen atoms, which may coordinate to the metal center, resulting in different modes of ligands. Finally, the amino group can act as a hydrogen donor that could contribute to the formation of a hydrogen-bonding network.

First of all, the three isomers have different bent angles when they coordinate to metals because the pyridyl N-donor (Npyridyl) lies in different sites in the same bridge part. Meantime, L2 and L3 will form different conformations when pyridyl cycles spin along the C-C bond between pyridyl cycles and triazole cycles. Finally, the amino group can act as a hydrogen donor that could contribute to the formation of a hydrogen-bonding network.

elements.content: In investigation of the effect of ligand isomerism on structural construction, the inorganic moiety is another important factor that may affect the coordination mode of ligands. In our study, copper(I) halogen was chosen as the inorganic moiety not only because copper(I) halogen units usually express various structural configurations but also because they can exhibit interesting fluorescent properties. In addition, according to the research of our group, Cu(I) often forms clusters with halogens which may change the coordination numbers of inorganic building units and influence the coordination mode of ligands.
elements.clean_text: In investigation of the effect of ligand isomerism on structural construction, the inorganic moiety is another important factor that may affect the coordination mode of ligands. In our study, copper(I) halogen was chosen as the inorganic moiety not only because copper(I) halogen units usually express various structural configurations but also because they can exhibit interesting fluorescent properties. In addition, according to the research of our group, Cu(I) often forms clusters with halogens which may change the coordination numbers of inorganic building units and influence the coordination mode of ligands.

elements.content: In this paper, 12 compounds exhibiting different dimensionalities (from 0D to 3D) were synthesized by reacting three isomers with different coordination modes (Scheme ) and various copper(I) halogen building units. All compounds were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Among these compounds, 4−6, 8, 9, and 12 exhibit interesting luminescent properties at room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1, L2, and L3, which were synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellet. Fluorescent emission spectra for the solid samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 luminescence spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of L1 (0.012 g, 0.05 mmol), CuCl (0.021 g, 0.1 mmol), acetonitrile (5 mL), and water (5 mL) was put in together and stirred for about 3 h. The solution was filtered. After the sample stood at room temperature for several days, red block crystals were isolated by hand. Yield: 18% (based on copper). Elemental analysis (%): Calc. For 1: C 42.73, H 2.97, N 24.93; Found: C 42.98, H 2.82, N 24.85. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3334(s), 3248(s), 3164(w), 1610(m), 1457(m), 1226(m), 893(s), 850(s).

elements.content: The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 2−4 and 9 were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4 kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. The data collection and the structural analysis of crystals 1, 5−8, and 10−12 were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections, and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20 ± 2 °C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determinations

The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 2-4 and 9 were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4 kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. The data collection and the structural analysis of crystals 1, 5-8, and 10-12 were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections, and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20 ± 2 °C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .

As shown in Figure , the Cu(I) atom lies in a tetrahedral sphere which consists of two chlorine atoms and two Npyridyl atoms from two distinct L1 molecules. The Cu−Cl bond length is in the normal range for this type of chlorine atom. The copper(I) atoms are linked by chlorine atoms, building up a 1D (CuCl)∞ chain along the b axis, which are further bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 to construct a 2D layer along the bc plane. The “castle-like” CuCl chain is very rare in contrast to the usual zigzag chain structures. Compound 1 is a 2D layer structure showing (4, 4) topology. Adjacent layers are arranged in an ABAB fashion. Hydrogen-bonding and π−π stacking interactions are both found in the structure as the main action force between two layers (Figure S1 in the ). Ntriazole atom of L1 does not coordinate to the metal atom in the crystal.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Structure of [CuCl(L1)] n  (1)

As shown in Figure , the Cu(I) atom lies in a tetrahedral sphere which consists of two chlorine atoms and two Npyridyl atoms from two distinct L1 molecules. The Cu-Cl bond length is in the normal range for this type of chlorine atom. The copper(I) atoms are linked by chlorine atoms, building up a 1D (CuCl)∞ chain along the b axis, which are further bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 to construct a 2D layer along the bc plane. The "castle-like" CuCl chain is very rare in contrast to the usual zigzag chain structures. Compound 1 is a 2D layer structure showing (4, 4) topology. Adjacent layers are arranged in an ABAB fashion. Hydrogen-bonding and π-π stacking interactions are both found in the structure as the main action force between two layers (Figure S1 in the ). Ntriazole atom of L1 does not coordinate to the metal atom in the crystal.

elements.content: To study the effect of anion on the self-assembly process at room temperature, CuI was used instead of CuCl under the same synthetic condition as for compound 1. In the asymmetric unit of crystal 2, Cu1, Cu2, and Cu3 atoms all display a tetrahedral coordination sphere (Figure ) and the Cu4 atom shows a trigonal coordination sphere. Among the three tetrahedral copper(I) atoms, Cu1 and Cu2 are coordinated by one Npyridyl atom and three μ3-bridge iodine atoms, respectively. The coordination sites of Cu3 atom are occupied by one nitrogen atom of L1, two μ3-bridge iodine atoms, and one μ2-bridge iodine atom (I4). The trigonal coordination sphere of Cu4 atom is constructed by one μ2-bridge iodine atom, one μ3-bridge iodine atom, and one Npyridyl atom. In the structure, eight copper(I) atoms are bridged by eight iodine atoms to bring out a 0D Cu8I8 “double-chain”. To the best of our knowledge, C8I8 units in the system of copper(I) halogen frameworks usually exhibit a double-cubane structure, while the “double-chain” structure units in compound 2 are rare. In the structure of 2, two neighboring “double-chain” units bond to each other by four L1 with Npyridyl atoms. In this way, the “double-chain” units are linked together by L2 to make up a 1D strap along the c-axis. Interestingly, I4 atom acts as the coordination terminal, which decreases the dimension of compound 2 compared with that of 1. The N−H···I hydrogen bonds form between nitrogen atoms of amino groups and iodine atoms in the “double-chains”. The hydrogen-bonding interactions play an important role in stabilizing the solid-state structure (Figure S2 in the ).

elements.content: Crystal 3 was obtained in the same vial as 2. As illustrated in Figure a, the geometries of the copper(I) atoms in the asymmetric unit of crystal 3 are trigonal and tetrahedral. The trigonal Cu(I) atoms are coordinated by one Npyridyl atom, one Ntriazole atom, and one μ2-bridge iodine atom, and the tetrahedral Cu(I) atoms are bonded by one Npyridyl atom, one Ntriazole atom, one μ2-bridge iodine atom, and one terminal iodine atom. A trigonal Cu(I) atom and a tetrahedral Cu(I) atom are linked by two iodine atoms successively to form a Cu2I2 unit. The Cu2I2 units are bridged by L1 through Npyridyl atoms forming a 1D chain along the c-axis direction. Adjacent 1D chains bridge each other to form a 2D layer structure in which Ntriazole atoms of one chain coordinate to Cu(I) atoms of another chain (Figure b). If the Cu2I2 unit is seen as a three-connected node and L1 is a tridentate spacer, the 2D layer exhibits (6, 3) topology. Two adjacent layers are stabilized by N−H···I hydrogen bonds, which are generated from iodine atoms and the hydrogen atoms of amino groups. The uncoordinated iodine fills the pore with the C−H···I interactions between iodine atoms and carbon atoms in the pyridyl cycles.

elements.content: Hydro(solvo)thermal conditions were introduced instead of room temperature conditions to construct compound 4. The geometries of the copper(I) atoms in the asymmetric unit of crystal 4 are trigonal and tetrahedral. As illustrated in Figure a, the Cu1 atom adopts a trigonal coordination sphere consisting of three iodine atoms. The Cu2 atom sits in a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere containing two iodine atoms, one Npyridyl atom, and one Ntriazole atom from two L1 molecules. It is worth noting that a Cu1 atom, two Cu2 atoms, and three iodine atoms form an unusual Cu3I3 unit. The Cu3I3 units are bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 forming a 1D zigzag chain along the b-axis. Two adjacent chains are further bridged by Ntriazole atoms forming a 2D wave-shape layer (Figure b). L1 molecule is a three-connected spacer and Cu3I3 unit is also a three-connected node. Therefore, the layer of compound 4 presents a (6, 3) net. It is worth noting that there are no π−π interactions between two layers in 4. This is because triazole cycles and pyridyl cycles are almost perpendicular to the layer plane, resulting in no overlap between aromatic rings of two layers. Compound 4 forms a 3D supramolecular net by N−H···I hydrogen bonding interactions of two layers, which is generated between iodine atoms and the hydrogen atoms from amino groups.

elements.content: In the hydrothermal synthesis system, Cu(II) has been used for constructing Cu(I) compounds by introducing a reducing agent in the reaction, which will yield compounds with different structures. X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 5 is a 3D coordination framework. As shown in Figure a, Cu(I) atoms show the same coordination environment in the structure. Each Cu(I) atom is coordinated by one Npyridyl atom of L1, one Ntriazole atom from distinct L1, and two μ2-Br atoms, forming a tetrahedral geometry. The Cu−N and Cu−Br bond lengths are considered normal. Two Cu(I) atoms are linked together by two bromine atoms to afford a 1D zigzag chain along the b-axis direction. Adjacent 1D chains are bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 to achieve a 2D layer. It is worth pointing out that the adjacent triazole cycles between two (CuBr)∞ in the layer are parallel to each other with amino groups in the opposite direction. The 2D layers are further bridged by Ntriazole atoms bonding to two copper(I) atoms to give rise to a complicated 3D framework (Figure b). In the crystal, the copper atom is viewed as a four-connected node, and the L1 molecule is a four-connected spacer. As a result, compound 5 exhibits a ZnCl2 net with {3.6.74}{3.62.73}2 topology.

Structure of [Cu2Br2(L1)] n  (5)

In the hydrothermal synthesis system, Cu(II) has been used for constructing Cu(I) compounds by introducing a reducing agent in the reaction, which will yield compounds with different structures. X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 5 is a 3D coordination framework. As shown in Figure a, Cu(I) atoms show the same coordination environment in the structure. Each Cu(I) atom is coordinated by one Npyridyl atom of L1, one Ntriazole atom from distinct L1, and two μ2-Br atoms, forming a tetrahedral geometry. The Cu-N and Cu-Br bond lengths are considered normal. Two Cu(I) atoms are linked together by two bromine atoms to afford a 1D zigzag chain along the b-axis direction. Adjacent 1D chains are bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 to achieve a 2D layer. It is worth pointing out that the adjacent triazole cycles between two (CuBr)∞ in the layer are parallel to each other with amino groups in the opposite direction. The 2D layers are further bridged by Ntriazole atoms bonding to two copper(I) atoms to give rise to a complicated 3D framework (Figure b). In the crystal, the copper atom is viewed as a four-connected node, and the L1 molecule is a four-connected spacer. As a result, compound 5 exhibits a ZnCl2 net with {3.6.74}{3.62.73}2 topology.

elements.content: In order to investigate the effect of anion on structural construction under hydrothermal conditions, the CuI for 4 was replaced by CuBr as reactant to build compound 6. As shown in Figure a, Cu(I) atom shows a distorted tetrahedral coordination sphere, being surrounded by one terminal bromine atom, two Npyridyl atoms, and one Ntriazole atom from three different L1. In the structure of compound 6, Cu(I) atoms are bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 forming a 1D zigzag chain along the a-axis. These zigzag chains are further connected to each other by Ntriazole atoms of a chain, bonding copper(I) atoms of the adjacent chain to form a 2D sheet extending along the ab plane with (4, 82) topology (Figure b). Strong hydrogen-bonding interactions are found between amino groups and bromine atoms of two adjacent layers. Moreover, π−π stacking interactions are also found between pyridyl rings with centroid−centroid separations of 3.66 Å. The above intermolecular interactions induce the 2D sheet to a 3D array, suggesting that the coeffects of hydrogen-bonding and π−π interactions are in favor of stabilizing the extended structure.

elements.content: In spite of the same reaction conditions as 5, a different structure is obtained for 7 because of different anions. In the structure of compound 7, the geometries of the copper(I) atoms in the asymmetric unit are trigonal and tetrahedral. The tetrahedral Cu1 is coordinated by one Ntriazole atom of a L1, one Npyridyl atom of another different L1, and two chlorine atoms. The trigonal Cu2 center is coordinated by two chlorine atoms and one Npyridyl atom of L1. The copper(I) atoms are bridged by chlorine atoms with μ2-bridge mode forming a 1D (CuCl)∞ chain along the b-axis. Adjacent chains are further bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L1 coordinating to copper(I) atom of (CuCl)∞ chain forming a 2D network extending along the bc plane (Figure a). It is interesting that the adjacent Ntriazole atoms between two (CuBr)∞ in the layer point to two sides of the plane. Adjacent planes linked through Ntriazole atoms in one plane link the four-coordinated copper(I) atom of adjacent planes forming a 3D framework (Figure b). From the view of topology, the copper atom exhibits two connecting fashions: three-connected and four-connected, and L1 is a three-connected spacer. As a result, compound 7 has a rare topology and its point (Schlafli) symbol for net is {6.82}2{6.85}.

elements.content: To explore the effect of ligand isomerism on the structure of compound, L1 was replaced by L2. In crystal 8, the Cu(I) atom adopts a tetrahedral geometry by bonding to one Ntriazole atom, one Npyridyl atom, and two bromine atoms. The distance between bromine atom and another copper(I) atom is 3.15 Å, which is slightly longer than normal. The copper(I) atoms are linked by Npyridyl atoms together with bromine atoms forming a 1D single chain along the b axis. Two 1D single chains are linked via Ntriazole atoms in a bidentate mode forming a double chain (Figure ). It is worth noting that L2 exhibits cisoid fashion here. The double chains are stabilized by hydrogen-bonding interactions and π−π interactions. It is the coeffects of hydrogen-bonding and π−π interactions that build up the 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S3 in the ).

As depicted in Figure , copper(I) atom displays a tetrahedral sphere coordinated by two Npyridiyl atoms from two different L2, one Ntriazole atom, and one terminal bromine atom. The copper(I) atom is bridged by Npyridyl atoms of L2 in cisoid fashion forming a 1D single chain. elements.content: To investigate the anion effect on the structural construction of compounds, compound 10 was built by replacing the I− anion with a Br− anion of compound 9. In compound 10, the Cu(I) atom is coordinated by two Npyridyl atoms of two different L2, two iodine atoms making a tetrahedral sphere. Two iodine atoms link two copper(I) atoms in μ2-bridge mode forming a Cu2I2 unit. Each Cu2I2 unit is linked by four different L2 constructing a windmill shaped structure. In this way, each windmill shape unit links adjacent Cu2I2 units to form a 2D layer with (4, 4) topology (Figure ). It is worth noting that unlike in compounds 8 and 9, L2 exhibits a transoid fashion in compound 10. Hydrogen-bonding and π−π interactions are both found between two adjacent layers, which serve as a key factor in building the 3D supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: The above reactions for L2 were introduced into a normal temperature system and compound 11 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the geometries of the copper(I) atoms in the asymmetric unit of crystal 3 are trigonal and tetrahedral. The tetrahedral Cu1 and Cu2 are both coordinated by one Npyridyl atom and one Ntriazole atom of two distinct L2 and two iodine atoms. The triangular Cu3 is bonded by three iodine atoms. The three copper(I) atoms are bridged by iodine atoms surrounding them, constructing a 1D (CuI)∞ chain along the b axis. Adjacent 1D chains are linked via Npyridyl atoms of L2 to give a 2D layer along the bc plane. Two 2D layers are bridged by Ntriazole atoms of one layer bonding to two four-coordinated copper(I) atoms of another layer forming a 2D double-layer (Figure b). L2 also exhibits a transoid fashion similar to 10. It is interesting that Ntriazole atoms in compound 11 all point to the inside of the double-layer. The arrangement of Ntriazole atoms limits its further linkage with other double-layers and decreases the dimension of the compound. But at the same time, it provides a chance for amino groups to point to the outside of double-layers. Therefore, N−H···I hydrogen bonds are found between amino groups and iodine atoms in two double-layers. Moreover, π−π stacking interactions are also found between pyridyl rings with centroid−centroid separations of 3.63 Å.

elements.content: With a different orientation of the Npyridyl donor, L3 will exhibit different coordination modes compared with L1 and L2. In compound 12, the Cu(I) atom is in tetrahedral coordination, coordinated by two iodine atoms and two nitrogen atoms of one L3 in a bidentate chelate coordination mode. Two copper(I) atoms are linked by two iodine atoms forming a Cu2I2 unit. Two L3 ligands chelate one Cu2I2 forming a zero periodic compound (Figure ). It is the terminal coordination mode of L3 that limits the dimension of compound 12. There are intramolecular hydrogen bond actions between nitrogen atoms of amino groups and uncoordinated Npyridyl atoms. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds are also found in crystal 12, which afford the compound a 1D chain structure. The 3D supramolecular architecture is obtained by π−π stacking interactions between aromatic cycles with centroid−centroid separations of 3.81 and 3.93 Å, respectively (Figure S5 in the ).
elements.clean_text:
Structure of Cu2I2(L3)2 (12)

With a different orientation of the Npyridyl donor, L3 will exhibit different coordination modes compared with L1 and L2. In compound 12, the Cu(I) atom is in tetrahedral coordination, coordinated by two iodine atoms and two nitrogen atoms of one L3 in a bidentate chelate coordination mode. Two copper(I) atoms are linked by two iodine atoms forming a Cu2I2 unit. Two L3 ligands chelate one Cu2I2 forming a zero periodic compound (Figure ). It is the terminal coordination mode of L3 that limits the dimension of compound 12. There are intramolecular hydrogen bond actions between nitrogen atoms of amino groups and uncoordinated Npyridyl atoms. Intermolecular hydrogen bonds are also found in crystal 12, which afford the compound a 1D chain structure. The 3D supramolecular architecture is obtained by π-π stacking interactions between aromatic cycles with centroid-centroid separations of 3.81 and 3.93 Å, respectively (Figure S5 in the ).

elements.content: The dimensionalities of coordination polymers mainly depend on the dimensionalities of inorganic building blocks and the connectivity of metal−organic−metal. As illustrated in Scheme , one 1D, four 2D, and two 3D compounds (1−7) are constructed for L1; two 1D and two 2D compounds (8−11) are built for L2; and one zero-periodic compound is established by L3.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Dimensionalities with Inorganic Building Blocks and Organic Ligands

The dimensionalities of coordination polymers mainly depend on the dimensionalities of inorganic building blocks and the connectivity of metal-organic-metal. As illustrated in Scheme , one 1D, four 2D, and two 3D compounds (1-7) are constructed for L1; two 1D and two 2D compounds (8-11) are built for L2; and one zero-periodic compound is established by L3.

elements.content: For L1, the dimensionality of inorganic building blocks is an important factor affecting the dimensionalities of the compounds. When the dimensionality of the inorganic building block is zero, we found that the dimensionalities of compounds 2−4 and 6 are mainly influenced by the coordination modes of L1 (Scheme ). The different coordination modes of L1 result in different connectivity of metal−organic−metal. L1 in B or C mode leads to the formation of the 2D structure compounds 3, 4, and 6, whereas compound 2 exhibits a 1D chain constructed by A mode. When the dimensionality of the inorganic building block is one, the dimensionalities of compounds 1, 5, and 7 also vary according to the coordination modes of L1. L1 with A mode yields compound 1 with a 2D layer compared with the 3D structures of 5 and 7 with B mode or C mode.

L1 with A mode yields compound 1 with a 2D layer compared with the 3D structures of 5 and 7 with B mode or C mode.

elements.clean_text: 2  The Diverse Structures Constructed by Three Isomers

elements.content: The compounds constructed by L2 include compounds 8−11. The dimensionality of inorganic building blocks is zero for 8−10. L2 in a cisoid fashion results in compounds 8 and 9, which show a 1D chain structure. L2 in a transoid fashion produces 2D compound 10. This means that transoid and cisoid fashions result in different dimensionalities of the compounds. When the dimensionality of inorganic building blocks is one, compound 11 with L2 is constructed. Because of the connectivity of metal−organic−metal, compound 11 is obtained as a mixed inorganic−organic layer.

The Npyridyl atom and Ntriazole atom form a five-membered ring structure with a metal atom. The connectivity of metal−organic−metal is zero here.

elements.content: In a word, the different dimensionalities of coordination compounds depend on the dimensionality of inorganic units (I n ) and metal−organic−metal connectivity (O n ) (Table ). When the dimensionality of inorganic unit (I n ) is zero, the O n changes from zero to two. The compounds show three different dimensionalities including molecular complexes (crystal 12), chain coordination polymers (crystal 2, 8, 9), and layered coordination polymers (crystal 3, 4, 6, 10), respectively. When the dimensionality of inorganic unit (I n ) is one, the O n changes from one to two. The compounds exhibit two different dimensionalities including mixed inorganic−organic layers (crystal 1 and crystal 11) and mixed inorganic−organic 3-D framework (crystal 5 and crystal 7).

The compounds exhibit two different dimensionalities including mixed inorganic-organic layers (crystal 1 and crystal 11) and mixed inorganic-organic 3-D framework (crystal 5 and crystal 7).

Besides the isomeric effect, the structures of the compounds can also be influenced by the anion effect, which is mainly reflected in two aspects. First, different anions have different radii. The difference in anion radius can change the relative distance of metals and bending angle of inorganic units, causing ligands to be in different coordination modes. Furthermore, anions can exhibit different bridge modes, such as terminal, μ2-bridge and μ3-bridge, which will form a variety of building units with copper(I) atoms.

Furthermore, anions can exhibit different bridge modes, such as terminal, μ2-bridge and μ3-bridge, which will form a variety of building units with copper(I) atoms.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4−6, 8, 9, 12 and the free ligands have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 645 nm for 4 when excited at 453 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 621 when excited at 450 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 576 nm with an excitation wavelength of 465 nm. Upon excitation at 392 nm, similar emissions are obtained at 541 and 556 nm for 8 and 9, respectively. Compound 12 exhibits an emission band at 525 nm with an excitation wavelength of 375 nm. The free ligands exhibit emissions maximum at 375 nm upon excitation at 215 nm. The fluorescent emissions could be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer. Alternatively, there could be halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and the coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4-6, 8, 9, 12 and the free ligands have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 645 nm for 4 when excited at 453 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 621 when excited at 450 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 576 nm with an excitation wavelength of 465 nm. Upon excitation at 392 nm, similar emissions are obtained at 541 and 556 nm for 8 and 9, respectively. Compound 12 exhibits an emission band at 525 nm with an excitation wavelength of 375 nm. The free ligands exhibit emissions maximum at 375 nm upon excitation at 215 nm. The fluorescent emissions could be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer. Alternatively, there could be halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and the coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.

elements.content: Twelve new Cu(I) coordination compounds exhibiting 0 to 3D structure have been synthesized under different synthetic conditions by using three n-bpt isomers as ligands. Meantime, anions act as terminals or bridges to decrease the coordination numbers or to form a variety of clusters, which play the role of tuning structure topology. The 0D to 3D compounds with diverse architectures and other interesting features are also found, such as supramolecular hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions, different dimensional framework, and molecular topology. The results suggest that the structural diversification of coordination compounds may result from the different coordination modes of isomerism n-bpt ligands and the role of different anions. Our current studies on ligand isomerism and anion effect are helpful in achieving further insights into the rational design and construction of diverse coordination compounds through the intelligent selection of the ligands and anions under corresponding conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Twelve new Cu(I) coordination compounds exhibiting 0 to 3D structure have been synthesized under different synthetic conditions by using three n-bpt isomers as ligands. Meantime, anions act as terminals or bridges to decrease the coordination numbers or to form a variety of clusters, which play the role of tuning structure topology. The 0D to 3D compounds with diverse architectures and other interesting features are also found, such as supramolecular hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions, different dimensional framework, and molecular topology. The results suggest that the structural diversification of coordination compounds may result from the different coordination modes of isomerism n-bpt ligands and the role of different anions. Our current studies on ligand isomerism and anion effect are helpful in achieving further insights into the rational design and construction of diverse coordination compounds through the intelligent selection of the ligands and anions under corresponding conditions.

A solution of L2 (0.024 g, 0.1 mmol) in CH3OH (5 mL) was layered onto a CuI (0.020 g, 0.11 mmol) solution of saturate KI water (5 mL). The solutions were left for several days at room temperature, and yellow crystals were obtained. Yield: 29% (based on copper). Elemental analysis (%): Calc. For 11: C 17.76, H 1.23, N 10.36; Found: C 17.98, H 1.17, N 10.22. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3304(m), 3178(w), 3064(w), 1596(m), 1470(s), 1407(s), 1369(w), 1204(w), 926(m), 780(s), 698(s).

Synthesis of Cu2I2(L3)2 (12)

The same synthetic procedure as for 11 was used except that L2 was replaced by L3, giving yellow block crystals. Yield: 23% (based on copper). Elemental analysis (%): Calc. For 12: C 33.57, H 2.33, N 19.58; Found: C 33.48, H 2.56, N 19.66. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3308(s), 3095(s), 2942(m), 1632(w), 1581(w), 1460(s), 1388(m), 1192(m), 979(s), 910(m), 812(s), 692(s).

cln_elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4−6, 8, 9, 12 and the free ligands have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 645 nm for 4 when excited at 453 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 621 when excited at 450 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 576 nm with an excitation wavelength of 465 nm. Upon excitation at 392 nm, similar emissions are obtained at 541 and 556 nm for 8 and 9, respectively. Compound 12 exhibits an emission band at 525 nm with an excitation wavelength of 375 nm. The free ligands exhibit emissions maximum at 375 nm upon excitation at 215 nm. The fluorescent emissions could be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer. Alternatively, there could be halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and the coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4-6, 8, 9, 12 and the free ligands have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 645 nm for 4 when excited at 453 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 621 when excited at 450 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 576 nm with an excitation wavelength of 465 nm. Upon excitation at 392 nm, similar emissions are obtained at 541 and 556 nm for 8 and 9, respectively. Compound 12 exhibits an emission band at 525 nm with an excitation wavelength of 375 nm. The free ligands exhibit emissions maximum at 375 nm upon excitation at 215 nm. The fluorescent emissions could be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer. Alternatively, there could be halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and the coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.
